articles.headline: A Whistle-Blower Who Can Name Names of Swiss Bank Account Holders
articles.snippet: Hervé Falciani, who claims his CD-ROMs have 130,000 account holders of Swiss bank accounts, has roiled politicians in Greece and Spain.
articles.abstract: Hervé Falciani, who claims his CD-ROMs have 130,000 account holders of Swiss bank accounts, has roiled politicians in Greece and Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hervé Falciani is a professed whistle-blower — the Edward Snowden of banking — who has been hunted by Swiss investigators, jailed by Spaniards and claims to have been kidnapped by Israeli Mossad agents eager for a glimpse of the client data he stole while working for a major financial institution in Geneva.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Press JPMorgan for an Admission of Wrongdoing
articles.snippet: Such an admission in a civil case against JPMorgan, related to the so-called London Whale trading loss, would set an important precedent for regulators.
articles.abstract: Such an admission in a civil case against JPMorgan, related to the so-called London Whale trading loss, would set an important precedent for regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | Federal regulators are seeking to level civil charges against JPMorgan Chase and extract a rare admission of wrongdoing from the nation’s biggest bank as an investigation into a multibillion-dollar trading loss enters its final stage.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Woes of Detroit Hurt Borrowing by Its Neighbors
articles.snippet: Two weeks after Detroit declared bankruptcy, cities, counties and other local governments in Michigan are getting a cold shoulder in the municipal bond market.
articles.abstract: Two weeks after Detroit declared bankruptcy, cities, counties and other local governments in Michigan are getting a cold shoulder in the municipal bond market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Detroit Effect has rippled all the way to Wall Street.

articles.headline: As Foreign Fighters Flood Syria, Fears of a New Extremist Haven
articles.snippet: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.
articles.abstract: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As foreign fighters pour into Syria at an increasing clip, extremist groups are carving out pockets of territory that are becoming havens for Islamist militants, posing what United States and Western intelligence officials say may be developing into one of the biggest terrorist threats in the world today.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Independent Agencies, Sometimes in Name Only
articles.snippet: Presidents generally choose the leaders of independent commissions, but the other members are picked on Capitol Hill, which means that the leaders can find it difficult to accomplish anything.
articles.abstract: Presidents generally choose the leaders of independent commissions, but the other members are picked on Capitol Hill, which means that the leaders can find it difficult to accomplish anything.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1985, President Ronald Reagan had to fill a Democratic slot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. He chose a young lawyer and economist, Joseph A. Grundfest.

articles.headline: Patent Case Has Potential to Give Apple the Upper Hand
articles.snippet: If the International Trade Commission decides on Friday that Samsung violated Apple patents, it could give Apple significant power in other patent feuds.
articles.abstract: If the International Trade Commission decides on Friday that Samsung violated Apple patents, it could give Apple significant power in other patent feuds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of years, Apple and its competitors have fought so many patent cases against one another in so many courts that keeping score has nearly become a fool’s errand.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Russia’s Stimulus Plan: Open the Gulag Gates
articles.snippet: With tens of thousands of business owners in the gulag system, and with a depressed economy, President Vladimir V. Putin has an unusual plan to turn things around.
articles.abstract: With tens of thousands of business owners in the gulag system, and with a depressed economy, President Vladimir V. Putin has an unusual plan to turn things around.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A business owner in Russia has a better chance of ending up in the penal colony system once known as the gulag than a common burglar does.

articles.headline: 2 E-Mail Services Shut Down to Protect Customer Data
articles.snippet: Lavabit shut down, hinting at a secret government order, and Silent Circle, a similar end-to-end encrypted e-mail provider, followed suit.
articles.abstract: Lavabit shut down, hinting at a secret government order, and Silent Circle, a similar end-to-end encrypted e-mail provider, followed suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shutdown of two small e-mail providers on Thursday illustrates why it is so hard for Internet companies to challenge secret government surveillance: to protect their customers’ data from federal authorities, the two companies essentially committed suicide.

articles.headline: Facing Loss of Capital, SAC Is Said to Talk of Layoffs
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors and the investment firm SAC Capital Advisors agreed on Thursday to a protective order that requires the firm to keep most of its money in its fund while operating under a criminal indictment, according to a person briefed on th...
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors and the investment firm SAC Capital Advisors agreed on Thursday to a protective order that requires the firm to keep most of its money in its fund while operating under a criminal indictment, according to a person briefed on the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | The beleaguered hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for investors to pull virtually all of their remaining money, a humbling blow to a once-powerful firm hobbled by criminal insider trading charges.

articles.headline: President Moves to Ease Worries on Surveillance
articles.snippet: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.
articles.abstract: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday sought to take control of the roiling debate over the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices, releasing a more detailed legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more openness and scrutiny of the N.S.A.’s programs to reassure a skeptical public that its privacy is not being violated.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Michael D. Shear
